item.title: Interpreting Grades
item.description: This note about grading and interpreting grades just adds some detail to what the course syllabus already says about grading. 4-point scale Grades in this course are assigned and calculated using Hofstra’s 4-point scale (described here in the Hofstra Bulletin). Following the Bulletin, the alphabetical grades, including plus (+) and minus (–), have the following 4-point scale values (and vice versa): letter 4pt Student’s academic performance … A 4.0 “was of honors level.

item.title: Test 2 Information
item.description: Our second test, on Wednesday May 18, will be in our regular classroom, but at our registrar-assigned time, 8 AM. It will be designed to take an hour or a little more than that. You will have until 10 AM to finish it. Content This test will cover the whole course, but with a strong emphasis on the second half. In the second half of the course, we covered three main topics and one smaller one.

item.title: Test 1 Information
item.description: Our first test will take place during class on March 16. Content We opened the course with the idea of logic, thinking about the possibility of a logic of scientific reasoning. We developed enough understanding of deductive logic to understand examples of it, and its strengths and limitations. We then contrasted it with the idea of inductive logic, thinking about its goals and limitations, as well. We considered, in a way that continued into our examination of various philosophers’s accounts, what roles deductive and inductive logic each might play in scientific reasoning.

item.title: Test 2 Questions
item.description: The questions for our second test follow. They stick very closely to your readings and what we emphasized in class. The test will consist of some of the questions on this list; it’s now incomplete. The questions selected for the test will appear on the test exactly as they are written here. There will be at least eight of them on the test, of which you will need to choose six to answer.
